review.title: Ontology Enrichment by Extracting Hidden Assertional Knowledge from Text
review.abstract: In this position paper we present a new approach for discovering some special classes of assertional knowledge in the text by using large RDF repositories, resulting in the extraction of new non-taxonomic ontological relations. Also we use inductive reasoning beside our approach to make it outperform. Then, we prepare a case study by applying our approach on sample data and illustrate the soundness of our proposed approach. Moreover in our point of view current LOD cloud is not a suitable base for our proposal in all informational domains. Therefore we figure out some directions based on prior works to enrich datasets of Linked Data by using web mining. The result of such enrichment can be reused for further relation extraction and ontology enrichment from unstructured free text documents.

sections.heading: B. Automatic Ontology Creation From Text
sections.text: Text2Onto covers the first five levels of the ontological learning stack [6 and 7]. AOEN covers only the level of the axiom schemata. HASTI [4] covers the level of terms, the hierarchical level of the concept, the level of relations, the general level of axioms. OntoLearn covers the first five levels. ATRACT covers the first three levels. Paramenidenes covers the first two levels [10 and 13] etc. To our knowledge, no system has ever been developed that covers all eight levels of the ontological learning stack. And no system has ever used linked data to improve the process of ontological learning from text.

sections.heading: LIMITATIONS OF THE NAMED ENTITIES
sections.text: Many methods of relation extraction limit the simultaneous occurrence of words within a sentence, and the non-ferrous pairs that occur in a sentence are assumed to occur simultaneously; however, there is no limit to the simultaneous occurrence of words in the real world. However, the larger the space we consider for the simultaneous occurrence of two words, the more time we need to search for the relationships of words, because the number of non-ferrous pairs is increasing. Many of such relationships may not be useful in our application, but we believe that the simultaneous occurrence of two words in a sentence can lead to some useful information under this two-component-in-text knowledge, as we have described in the related scenario. sections.heading: VIII. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this paper, we propose a novel approach to extract hidden or implicit information from texts from which new ontological relationships can be derived. We have shown that the use of linked data can improve the problem of context awareness in the case of an automatic ontological learning process. In this context, we have proposed an algorithm to enrich the non-taxonomic relationships in texts. We have shown that this algorithm can find new non-taxonomic relationships.
